title: seeking best match for typeface from 17th-century engraving--
content:
For an event poster, I'd like to replace the original text, attached, (from a 17th-century engraving that is the centerpiece of the poster) with information about the current event (title, date, location). And I'd like this information to appear in a font that emulates the original typeface as much as possible.

What font would be the best match here to convey a feel for the period?

Suggestions much appreciated.

Thanks!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141228194151im_/http:/typophile.com/files/ANewSystem-type_4366.jpg)
author: sfreund

comments.content: It's a bit of a different feel, but [Lagarto](http://web.archive.org/web/20141228194151/http:/kimeratype.com/) (click on English, then KTF type gallery) came to mind. The only other one I could think of is Storm's [Antique](http://web.archive.org/web/20141228194151/http:/www.stormtype.com/typefaces-fonts-shop/families-63-antique) suite.

Sirenne from MVB fonts would be a great choice:

[http://www.mvbfonts.com/html/fonts/sirenne/pk\_sirenne\_display.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20141228194151/http:/www.mvbfonts.com/html/fonts/sirenne/pk_sirenne_display.htm "http://www.mvbfonts.com/html/fonts/sirenne/pk\_sirenne\_display.htm")
I second Sirenne: it's fantastic. Plus, you have various optical weights to do a great composition.
